awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating differential data collection among migrants, aid workers, and officials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Political and environmental turmoil have led to the displacement of individuals from their homes. Documenting mobile populations facilitates efforts to ameliorate the effects of displacement. Documentation of mobile populations is also challenging as individuals move through various temporary facilities and housing arrangements while en route. Moreover, the traits of individuals – both migrants and those with whom migrants interact – affect how migrant characteristics and movements are documented, creating poorly understood variation in the process of documentation. This doctoral dissertation research uses theory from governance and cultural anthropology to understand how the intersections of individual attributes affect migrant interactions with aid workers and government officials. In addition to supporting the training of a graduate student in anthropology in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project enhances scientific understandings by broadly disseminating its findings to relevant stakeholders and policy makers. 

Specifically, this research project investigates how different data collection technologies are employed by aid workers and government officials as they interact with heterogeneous migrants. The doctoral student uses ethnographic and archival methods to answer research questions focusing on how aid workers and government officials understand and use data collection technologies, and how individual characteristics of the workers, officials, and migrants affect the use of different technologies. These findings offer guidance to humanitarian actors, agencies, and policy makers interested in better understanding which data collection strategies and associated practices are most effective in achieving positive outcomes for individuals and communities affected by migration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, more than two million asylum-seeking migrants from around the world were immobilized in Mexican border cities before starting any asylum or border crossing process into the United States. This 26-month long qualitative study, supported by an NSF DDRIG, investigates the encounters between asylum seekers, Mexican aid workers, and American software engineers and state officials in order to understand how digital innovation projects for US border control have affected transnational humanitarian practices and promoted automated data collection technologies for legal migration management amid shrinking asylum protections for vulnerable, displaced populations.

Through extensive participant-observation in two Mexican migrant shelters and 72 ethnographic interviews, the study demonstrates how changing US migration policies transformed these humanitarian spaces into sites of racialized surveillance where global migrants experience and resist various forms of monitoring and social sorting, from administrative and video surveillance to biometric verification, geofencing and GPS tracking. As the use of mobile technologies to manage US-bound migration becomes commonplace, aid workers scramble for hours helping migrants figure out how to use the CBP One Mobile Application amid providing other legal, medical and psycho-social support. In their everyday encounters, Mexican aid workers and migrants engage in expressive cultural performances through intercultural jests that promote solidarity among each other and also provide opportunities to individually and collectively contest shifting state power inequalities in contexts of transit migration--a process that, contrary to popular political belief, is replete with surveillance of migrant lives. Automated processes are re-shaping human relationships and decision-making behavior in contemporary life through the daily use of mobile devices and digital systems developed by software engineers. This project shows that the development and implementation of CBP One has caused administrative upheaval for shelters and personal conundrums in migration strategies as people decide to use or circumvent the app in their journeys. Overall, by providing polyvocal perspectives of differently positioned actors along the migrant trail, this study highlights how spaces like migrant shelters become important sites for understanding the social effects of digital technological developments for border and asylum management on migrant populations and the aid providers in third countries who help them construct liveable futures in waiting.

This anthropological study also sheds light on the global politics of border re-territorialization that remake the geographical boundaries of states and displace them onto migrant bodies and thier digital devices in times of humanitarian crises. Digital borders might be everywhere but their effects depend on specific geographic, cultural, racialized, and gendered contexts that shape the extent to which individuals, whether citizens or noncitizens, are reticulated and made vulberable through their bodily and technological matter within automated social worlds that blur the terms of sanctuary, solidarity and surveillance.
